title: Top Girls: middle class privilege and agentic practice
abstractText:
This study aims to extend a recently completed piece of work on agentic practice among privileged young women (see Maxwell and Aggleton, 2010). 

First, the research will examine how these young women might be acting powerfully across various aspects of their lives, including their education, in relationships with peers and family. 

Second, the study will continue to make more visible the 'real' lives of  'top girls' - young women who appear to have the greatest opportunities open to them to achieve and become who they would like. 

Third, it will add to debates concerning the nature of our middle classes, and how different values and outlooks within the middle classes influence young women's attitudes and experiences of the world, and their relationships to other social groups. 

The study will involve four fee-paying schools in one area of the South East of England.  Using participant observation, focus group discussions and in-depth (repeated) interviews, at least 30 young women in their GCSE years and the Sixth Form from each school will take part in the research.
